SEARCH
Package uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop

Interface ICommandLine

All Known Implementing Classes:
Main, OOPrailwaySim
public interface ICommandLine
Interface that defines a command-line processing capability. Classes implementing this interface must provide a method to process text commands.

This interface is used for creating interactive programs that respond to user input from a command line or text field. When a user types a command and presses Enter, the processCommand(String) method is called with the entered text.

Why use an interface? Interfaces define a contract - they specify what methods a class must have without dictating how those methods work. This allows different classes to implement command processing in their own way while ensuring they all have the same method signature.

Example Implementation:

 public class MySimulation implements ICommandLine {
     @Override
     public void processCommand(String command) {
         if (command.equals("start")) {
             startSimulation();
         } else if (command.equals("stop")) {
             stopSimulation();
         } else {
             System.out.println("Unknown command: " + command);
         }
     }
 }

    void
    processCommand(String command)
    Processes a command entered by the user.

  • Method Details

    • processCommand

      void processCommand(String command)
      Processes a command entered by the user. This method is called when the user types text and presses Enter.

      Implementing classes should parse the command string and perform the appropriate action. For example, "start" might start a simulation, "add locomotive 5 10" might add a locomotive at position (5,10).

      Parameters:
      command - the text entered by the user (e.g., "start", "stop", "add carriage")
